context.item: You will analyze page scans searching for "educational transcript" elements.
Your task is to identify and extract structured academic records that document a student's coursework, grades, credits, and academic progress over time.

Educational transcripts may take forms including: K-12 transcripts, college/university transcripts, graduate school transcripts, community college transcripts, vocational/technical school transcripts, professional development transcripts, continuing education transcripts, and international academic records.

An educational transcript is defined as: an official or unofficial document issued by an educational institution that provides a comprehensive record of a student's academic history, including courses taken, grades earned, credits awarded, cumulative performance metrics, and degrees or credentials conferred.

The following are NOT educational transcripts: single-term report cards, individual course grade sheets, diplomas or certificates alone, course catalogs, class schedules, enrollment verification letters, degree audit worksheets, or academic planning documents.

Use two-step verification: first identify potential transcript elements by scanning for institutional headers, student information, course listings, and grade tables, then verify these meet the strict criteria of comprehensive academic records.
If none found, respond with not_found format.
When in doubt, prioritize accuracy over comprehensiveness.

Transcripts typically contain: institutional identification, student identifying information, enrollment dates, course codes and titles, credit hours, grades or marks, term/semester organization, cumulative GPA or performance metrics, and registrar authentication.
Transcripts may span multiple pages and include legends explaining grading scales, academic policies, transfer credits, and degree requirements.
Official transcripts often include security features such as watermarks, official seals, registrar signatures, issue dates, and statements about authenticity.
Recognize that transcript formats vary widely by institution, country, educational level, and time period, but all share the core function of documenting cumulative academic achievement.
